summary: This is the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2013 Trust Agreement, dated September 16, 2013, establishing a trust with Epstein as Grantor and three individuals as Trustees. The document outlines the administration of the trust during Epstein's life and after his death, including specific bequests totaling millions of dollars to named individuals and the forgiveness of loans. It details plans for several of Epstein's properties to be placed into separate trusts for the benefit of a primary beneficiary, with Eva Andersson Dubin as a key contingent beneficiary.

events.title: Execution of Jeffrey E. Epstein 2013 Trust
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signs the trust agreement establishing 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2013 Trust,' naming three Trustees and outlining the distribution of his assets during his life and after his death.

Territory of the United States Virgin Islands (governing law and situs)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein established a revocable trust in 2013, reserving extensive control over assets during his lifetime, including the power to amend, revoke, or withdraw principal at will.
The trust document lists specific bequests of $5 million each to Ghislaine Maxwell, Karyna Shuliak, Jean Luc Brunel, and Darren Indyke (plus an interest in KCAC, LLC), among others.
Epstein forgave loans made to several individuals, including Jean Luc Brunel, Mark Epstein, and associates like Gaddo Cardini, Robert Gold, and Steven Victor.

The trust outlines plans for several of Epstein's high-value properties (in Paris, New York, Little St. James Island, New Mexico, and Florida) to be placed into separate 'residence trusts' for the benefit of a primary, unnamed female beneficiary.
Eva Andersson Dubin is named as the key contingent beneficiary, set to inherit the residuary trust and the proceeds from the property trusts if the primary beneficiary does not survive.
